etymologies: mid 18th century; earliest use found in Philip Miller (1691–1771), horticulturist and writer. From scientific Latin Rivina, genus name from the name of Augustus Quirinus Rivinus, Latinized form (from classical Latin rīvus stream + -īnus) corresponding to the German surname of August Bachmann (literally ‘man from the brook’), German botanist

definitions: Any plant of the genus Rivina (family Phytolaccaceae), comprising perennial shrubs native to tropical America, typically having inconspicuous white to pale pink flowers and bright red berries; especially the bloodberry, R. humilis, commonly grown for ornament. Also (in form Rivina): the genus itself.

notes.text: Valid publication of the genus name: Linnaeus Species plantarum (1753) I. 121.
